column9: attracting public approval and praise.
column10: Following on from the acclaimed 'Funny English Signs' series...
column11: She is an acclaimed author.
column12: The film has been widely acclaimed by critics.

column9: to laugh at someone, often by copying them in a funny but unkind way.
column10: By the way, I don't mean to mock people's errors in English.
column11: The other children mocked him for his accent.
column12: She made a gesture that mocked the way he walked.

column9: subjected to contemptuous and dismissive language or behavior.
column10: I think it's really important to make sure my learners of English don't feel judged or ridiculed.
column11: He was ridiculed for his unusual ideas.
column12: She felt ridiculed by her colleagues' comments.

column9: to say something suddenly and unexpectedly.
column10: But sometimes, people just come out with really funny things...
column11: He comes out with the strangest things sometimes.
column12: She came out with a brilliant suggestion.

column9: feeling very embarrassed or ashamed.
column10: We can choose how we react to them - feel mortified, or laugh it off...
column11: I was mortified when I realized I had called him by the wrong name.
column12: She was absolutely mortified to see her ex-boyfriend with a new partner.

column9: to respond to a difficult or embarrassing situation by making a joke of it.
column10: ...or laugh it off, learn from it and move on.
column11: He tried to laugh off the embarrassing incident.
column12: When she fell over, she just laughed it off.

column9: the state of being unable to do something.
column10: My inability to pronounce the word water - 'eau'.
column11: His inability to speak French was a disadvantage.
column12: The company's inability to adapt led to its failure.

column9: funny without being intended to be.
column10: ...offer some corrections, so we can all learn from these unintentionally hilarious mistakes.
column11: The film was so bad it was unintentionally hilarious.
column12: His serious speech became unintentionally hilarious when his trousers fell down.

column9: to make something completely clean and free from bacteria.
column11: They sanitised all the gym equipment after use.
column12: The water is sanitised with chlorine.

column9: An error for 'sanitise'; it implies making something evil or related to Satan.
column11: What could 'satanising' your hands mean? Doing something evil or sinful with them I suppose.
column12: This sign is a funny mistake; it should say 'sanitise', not 'satanise'.

column9: water that has been blessed by a priest and is used in religious ceremonies.
column10: You will need holy water to clean this off.
column11: He sprinkled the congregation with holy water.
column12: In horror movies, holy water is often used to fight vampires.

column9: a phrase from the proverb 'The devil makes work for idle hands', meaning people who are not busy are more likely to get into trouble.
column10: They say the devil makes work for idle hands - apparently this is the place to do it.
column11: The youth club was set up to keep kids off the streets and give their idle hands something to do.
column12: It's important to stay busy; you know what they say about idle hands.

column9: wicked and immoral; committing a sin.
column10: Doing something evil or sinful with them I suppose.
column11: It feels sinful to eat so much chocolate.
column12: The preacher warned the congregation against sinful behaviour.

column9: the act or process of repairing and improving a building.
column11: The museum is closed for renovation.
column12: They are planning a major renovation of their house.

column9: a forcible overthrow of a government or social order in favour of a new system.
column11: The French Revolution began in 1789.
column12: The country is on the brink of revolution.

column9: in a way that is wrong or based on a wrong opinion or understanding.
column10: ...when Mori met Obama, he mistakenly said 'Who are you?'...
column11: I mistakenly took the wrong train.
column12: She mistakenly believed he was her friend.

column9: completely forbidden by rules or law.
column11: Smoking is strictly prohibited in this area.
column12: Photography is strictly prohibited inside the museum.

column9: words governing, and usually preceding, a noun or pronoun and expressing a relation to another word or element in the clause.
column11: 'In', 'on', and 'at' are common prepositions of place.
column12: He often makes mistakes with prepositions.

column9: 'Exiting' means leaving a place. 'Existing' means living or being real.
column10: PLEASE PAY YOUR PARKING FEE BEFORE EXISTING. (Error)
column11: Please pay your fee before exiting. (Correction)
column12: He was seen exiting the building. / It is the oldest existing building in the city.

column9: a sudden attack of illness, especially a stroke or an epileptic fit.
column11: He had a seizure and collapsed.
column12: The flashing lights can trigger a seizure in people with epilepsy.

column9: a sudden, uncontrolled attack of a medical condition, such as epilepsy; a sudden outburst of emotion.
column11: She had a fit of giggles and couldn't stop laughing.
column12: The child threw a fit when he didn't get what he wanted.

column9: a salad of romaine lettuce and croutons dressed with parmesan cheese, lemon juice, olive oil, egg, Worcestershire sauce, garlic, and black pepper.
column10: Clearly this is supposed to be a Caesar Salad.
column11: I'll have the Caesar salad with chicken.
column12: He makes a delicious Caesar salad dressing.

column9: having or showing a cautious distrust of someone or something; suggesting that something is wrong or illegal.
column11: The police were called to investigate a suspicious package.
column12: I'm suspicious of his motives.

column9: not having or showing the necessary skills to do something successfully.
column10: Keep it away from incompetent people...
column11: He is an incompetent manager.
column12: The project failed due to incompetent leadership.

column9: exposed to the possibility of being attacked or harmed, either physically or emotionally.
column10: It would be better to say 'vulnerable people'.
column11: Old people are particularly vulnerable to the flu.
column12: She was feeling very vulnerable and alone.

column9: in a situation where something unpleasant might happen.
column11: Children from poor families are more at risk of developing health problems.
column12: The company is at risk of going bankrupt.

column9: regulatory substances produced in an organism and transported in tissue fluids such as blood to stimulate specific cells or tissues into action.
column11: Teenagers often have fluctuating hormones.
column12: Hormone levels can affect your mood.

column9: to get rid of something unwanted, especially by leaving it in a place where it is not allowed to be.
column11: People who dump rubbish illegally will be fined.
column12: He dumped his old computer at the recycling centre.

column9: to have a firm belief in the reliability, truth, ability, or strength of someone or something.
column11: You have to trust in your own abilities.
column12: She has a deep trust in her friends.

column9: to push (something or someone) suddenly or violently in a specified direction.
column11: He thrust the letter into my hand.
column12: She thrust her way through the crowd.

column9: to interrupt the sleep, relaxation, or privacy of someone.
column11: Please do not disturb the other guests.
column12: I'm sorry to disturb you, but can I ask you a question?

column9: having or showing signs of mental or emotional problems.
column10: I AM ALL READY VERY DISTAB. (Error for 'I am already very disturbed').
column11: The film was so violent it left me feeling disturbed for days.
column12: He is a deeply disturbed young man.

column9: 1. (verb) to make a sudden, sharp movement. 2. (slang noun) a stupid or unpleasant person. 3. (slang verb) to masturbate.
column11: The car jerked to a halt.
column12: Don't be such a jerk!
column13: The sign is a humorous mistake, likely meaning 'Don't make sudden movements while driving'.

column9: 'Treats' are special things that you enjoy. 'Threats' are statements of an intention to inflict pain, injury, damage, or other hostile action.
column11: The dog gets treats when it behaves well.
column12: He received death threats from an unknown source.

column9: a tap or valve for controlling the flow of a liquid or gas. (Also a vulgar slang term for a penis).
column11: The emergency cock is another word for an emergency stop valve.
column12: Because of its double meaning, it's better to use 'tap' or 'valve' in public signs.

column9: manipulating (someone) by psychological means into questioning their own sanity.
column11: He was gaslighting her into believing she was the one with the problem.
column12: Gaslighting is a form of emotional abuse.

column9: the action of erecting a building or other structure; a state in which the penis becomes rigid and enlarged.
column11: The erection of the new bridge will take two years.
column12: The sign is funny because 'erection' has a common sexual meaning.

column9: in the process of being built or made.
column10: The correct sign would be 'Under construction'.
column11: The new shopping centre is still under construction.
column12: The road is closed because the bridge is under construction.

column9: 'Genital' relates to the reproductive organs. 'Gentle' means kind, mild, or soft.
column11: This should be a 'gentle reminder'.
column12: He has a very gentle manner. / The doctor examined his genital area.

column9: not allowed; banned.
column10: It is forbidden to upload and download fish.
column11: It is forbidden to walk on the grass.
column12: Smoking is forbidden in the building.
